keyDevelopments: New administration's first six months established policy direction
Initial executive orders on immigration, trade, and regulatory reform
DOJ leadership transition completed with new priorities announced

changes.summary: Escalation of executive actions and early institutional friction
keyDevelopments: First wave of inspector general dismissals announced
Trade tariff increases on China and European goods
Congressional oversight requests increasingly ignored

categoryChanges.rationale: Firing of 17 inspectors general in single action; courts ruled action unlawful but declined to order reinstatement
Liberation Day tariffs announced; 10% baseline on all imports with higher rates for China

changes.summary: Intelligence community concerns emerge; regulatory shifts accelerate
keyDevelopments: Sen. Warner's floor speech warning of intelligence politicization
CIA workforce buyout offer to entire agency
Schedule F executive order reinstated, reclassifying career positions

categoryChanges.rationale: DNI began reassigning analysts who produced assessments contradicting administration narratives; security clearance revocations increased
Pace of executive orders accelerated to 20+ per month; contradictory guidance created compliance uncertainty

changes.summary: Election administration concerns intensify ahead of midterms
keyDevelopments: 16 states enacted 29 new restrictive voting laws
DOJ requested voter registration files from most states
University funding threats escalated with Harvard grant termination

categoryChanges.rationale: Wave of state voting restrictions took effect; proof-of-citizenship requirements advanced in multiple states
FCC opened investigations into major networks; university compact demands issued with funding consequences

changes.summary: Judicial conflicts escalate; DOJ independence concerns mount
keyDevelopments: Deputy AG declared administration 'at war' with federal judiciary
100+ DOJ prosecutors resigned citing political interference
Threats against federal judges tripled from prior decade

categoryChanges.rationale: NYC Bar Association condemned DOJ 'war on judiciary' remarks; mass prosecutor resignations over politically-motivated case decisions
January 6 pardons issued for ~1,500 defendants including seditious conspiracy convictions; historians warned of political violence normalization

changes.summary: Federal Reserve independence threatened; year-end institutional strain
keyDevelopments: Attempt to fire Fed Governor Lisa Cook
DOJ probe of Federal Reserve announced
Intelligence Authorization Act included politicization safeguards

categoryChanges.rationale: Unprecedented attempt to remove Fed governor; DOJ investigation of Fed signaled executive branch interference with monetary policy
DNI fired National Intelligence Council officials over Venezuela assessment; intelligence resources diverted to Greenland proposal

changes.summary: One-year mark shows sustained institutional pressure across all domains
keyDevelopments: Overall risk elevated to High (7.3) from Elevated baseline
All 10 categories show 'increasing' trend direction
Rule of Law domain highest at 8.0 average

categoryChanges.rationale: Cumulative effect of 108 restrictive laws since 2020; 28 new restrictions taking effect before 2026 midterms
Schedule F implementation affecting 50,000 federal employees; systematic replacement of career staff with political appointees
